meanings.definition: Take back or regain possession of (something)
meanings.sent1: I had to retake my toy from my little brother.
meanings.sent2: She wanted to retake her book from the shelf.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to retake its favorite toy from the playful puppy.
meanings.sent4: The team was determined to retake the lead in the final minutes of the game.
meanings.sent5: After losing the game, he vowed to retake his pride and confidence.

meanings.definition: To take a test or exam again
meanings.sent1: I need to retake the math test to improve my grade.
meanings.sent2: She was disappointed to retake the exam due to illness.
meanings.sent3: The student had to retake the test after forgetting to study.
meanings.sent4: He decided to retake the exam to prove his knowledge.
meanings.sent5: After failing the first time, she was determined to retake the test and pass.

meanings.sent1: The photographer had to retake the picture to get the perfect shot.
meanings.sent2: They had to retake the scene because of a technical issue.
meanings.sent3: The director asked the actors to retake the scene for better lighting.
meanings.sent4: The filmmaker decided to retake the shot to capture the emotion accurately.
meanings.sent5: The photographer wanted to retake the photo to capture the moment perfectly.
